head.title: Connection between Confidence Intervals and Sampling Distributions

body.p: The purpose of this activity is to help give you a better understanding of the underlying reasoning behind the interpretation of confidence intervals. In particular, you will gain a deeper understanding of why we say that we are "95% confident that the population mean is covered by the interval."
The green line marks the value of the population mean, μ.

To begin the simulation, click the Sample button at the top of the applet. You will see a line segment appear underneath the distribution; you should see that the line segment has a dot in the middle.

You have used the simulation to select a single sample from the population; the applet has automatically computed the mean (
x ¯
) of your sample; your
x ¯
value is represented by the dot in the middle of the line segment. The line segment represents a confidence interval. Notice that, by default, the applet uses a 95% confidence interval for μ.
If your confidence interval did cover the population mean μ, then the applet will have recorded 1 "hit," noted at the top of the applet.
Now, click to select another single sample.
Notice that the total number of samples is tallied near the top of the applet.
Now, click Sample 50 repeatedly until the applet tallies a "total" of around 1,000 samples. You will see that the applet computes the percentage of hits for all the intervals.
